22 November 2021Data Collection
We conducted 40 in-depth interviews across seven cities: Cincinnati, London, Los Angeles, Paris, San Francisco, Toronto, and New York (see for participant information). We interviewed five high-profile influencers; seven agents from three prominent talent agencies; five executives from three multinational brands; 17 practitioners from six global public relations and digital analytics agencies; and six other experts in the influencer industry (e.g., reporters). Given the exploratory nature of the research, our initial goal was to broadly understand influencer advertising strategies and practices. The sample was selected to provide diverse expert perspectives on this topic. However, as is often the case with qualitative research, research questions can emerge from the “empirical phenomena” (either specific contexts or types of behaviors; Belk, Fischer, and Kozinets 2012, p. 17; Corbin and Strauss 1990). Thus, the research questions crystallized through iterative data collection and analysis, where interviewing provided a vehicle for theoretical sampling.
We assembled a list of high-profile SMIs based on prominent rankings (e.g., Forbes Top Influencers), with followers ranging from 100,000 to more than 2 million. This sample was theoretically grounded given these influencers’ experiences with acquiring celebrity capital and partnering with well-known consumer brands (e.g., Nike, Coca-Cola). We contacted influencers either by messaging them directly on social media or through their agents, resulting in a sample of five elite influencers (e.g., Michelle Phan, Blair Fowler). To capture the client side of influencer advertising and celebrification, we interviewed five executives from three premier consumer brands (e.g., Procter & Gamble, McDonald’s). Simultaneously, we assembled a list of companies, talent agencies, public relation firms, and digital analytics agencies known for influencer advertising. The talent agencies were included in the sample if they had an influencer management department or equivalent and a history of representing influencers for a minimum of five years. For example, United Talent Agency developed a YouTube Management Division in 2006. We interviewed seven practitioners from three talent agencies (e.g., Digital Brand Architects, Style Coalition).
The public relations firms and digital analytics agencies included in the sample were selected based on the following criteria: an international presence, representation of high-profile brands, and experience with high-profile influencers. We interviewed 17 practitioners from six agencies (e.g., Brandwatch, Burson-Marsteller). Additional influencer industry experts were selected to provide a more holistic view of the influencer industry. A list of examples of influencers signed with these agencies and brands represented is available from the authors by request. We interviewed industry professionals across four companies, including mainstream media outlets (e.g., The Financial Times, Vogue) and novel digital startups.
Each semistructured interview (Mick and Buhl 1992; Thompson, Locander, and Pollio 1989) lasted between one and two hours and took place either in person or via Skype. Interviews were recorded and subsequently transcribed. We carefully compiled analytical field notes throughout the interviews to capture the interview setting and record observations, in line with Corbin and Strauss (1990). This process yielded more than 65 pages of handwritten notes and more than 275 pages of single-spaced pages of transcript text.
Interview guides were developed for each type of participant. Open-ended questions extended from the initial literature review and research problem. Our questions focused on the relationships influencers have with their audiences; how they maintain and grow those relationships; how they choose to work with certain brands over others; how brands and public relations firms see their roles in the industry; and how talent agencies discover and/or grow influencer talent. In line with the grounded theory approach, participants were probed (e.g., “Tell me more”) to elicit richer insights and to fill narrative gaps (Hallberg 2006). This allowed for a more fluid conversation (Gibson and Brown 2009) and for clarification related to emergent theoretical concepts, as data analysis proceeded in parallel with data collection. Each participant signed a consent form and reviewed his or her interview transcript for accuracy. We did not receive any follow-up requests to edit transcripts. Participants were not compensated.
Data Analysis
This qualitative study employs an iterative process of coding and recoding the data, in line with constant comparison in grounded theory (Creswell and Poth 2017). The first two authors analyzed the data following a process of initial, open, axial, and selective coding (Corbin and Strauss 1990). First, in initial coding, words, phrases, and large blocks of data were abstracted under conceptual headings. Next, we used open coding to identify similarities and differences by constantly comparing concepts with new data, which in turn led to new concepts. Then, we coded for relationships between emerging concepts, referred to as axial coding. Finally, core theoretical categories emerged via selective coding. Concepts initially identified continued to reappear in our data confirming their theoretical significance and the basis of our conceptual framework. Themes were constructed based on an identification of narrative repetitions, similarities, and differences (Bogdan and Taylor 1975). We examined, compared, conceptualized, and categorized the data into distinct units of meaning (Parker, Ang, and Koslow 2018), which led to further conceptual refinement. Throughout the process, theoretical memos were compiled as written records of analysis. As we drafted early versions of the findings, we circled back to the original research questions, explored relevant literature, created illustrative diagrams, and solicited reviewer feedback. These activities contributed to theoretical saturation, guided by the data and grounded in concepts of celebrity capital, celebrification, and influencer advertising.
Findings
Emergent from our findings is a process capturing how influencers acquire celebrity capital, which we term influencer celebrification. Influencer celebrification is defined as the process by which SMIs acquire celebrity capital within an interconnected social media advertising ecosystem. We identify three types of practices in the influencer celebrification process: generative practices, collaborative practices, and evaluative practices. These are conceived of as iterative practices within the influencer celebrification process. That is, influencer celebrification is not linear but rather represents overlapping and often concurrent practices by which influencers acquire celebrity capital. Our framework of influencer celebrification further highlights the role of advertising industry practitioners in propelling influencers to acquire celebrity capital. Collectively, the influencer celebrification process produces celebrity capital, which can be leveraged for commercial means through influencer advertising.
First, generative practices initiate an influencer’s acquisition of celebrity capital. Influencers work tirelessly to build their following (i.e., attention labor) and develop niche content that can extend beyond a single platform (i.e., platform agnosticism). Here, advertising industry practitioners act as talent scouts in the influencer celebrification process, seeking the “next big thing” but recognizing that the acquisition of celebrity capital begins with the influencer.
Second, collaborative practices expand an influencer’s acquisition of celebrity capital by deepening connections between influencers, fans, and advertising industry practitioners. Influencers enrich relationships with their fans across multiple platforms (i.e., audience portability) and collectively conceive of creative content with advertising industry practitioners and followers (i.e., creative ideation). Here, advertising industry practitioners act as creative concierges in the influencer celebrification process, leveraging unexpected opportunities for the influencer.
Third, evaluative practices legitimize an influencer’s acquisition of celebrity capital by placing valuation on the worth and potential of an influencer to deliver meaningful promotional value for a brand. Influencers are appraised based on their ability to gain online community buy-in for a brand partner (i.e., community-centric KPIs) and evaluated by the reach of their content across porous social media borders (i.e., content traversal). Here, advertising industry practitioners act as impact analysts in the influencer celebrification process, assessing an influencer’s relevance and potential for success.
Utilizing Figure 2 as an organizing visual framework, we describe how influencer celebrification unfolds through iterative practices and the integral role of advertising industry practitioners. Influencer celebrification is a synergistic process of acquiring celebrity capital, where the combined effect of all practices exceeds the sum of their individual impacts. Within this iterative process, attention labor, audience portability, and community-centric KPIs generate community-oriented synergistic effects, while platform agnosticism, creative ideation, and content traversal produce content-oriented synergistic effects. Figure 3 categorizes and defines these emergent concepts within a matrix of influencer celebrification practices and synergistic effects. Below, we define and illustrate each practice with exemplary cases from the data.

### Generative Practices in the Influencer Celebrification Process

The process begins with generative practices that initiate the acquisition of celebrity capital. Two key generative practices are attention labor and platform agnosticism. Advertising practitioners function as talent scouts, not to “discover” influencers, but to identify those already becoming celebrified independently.

**Attention Labor**  
Influencers invest significant entrepreneurial effort—termed attention labor—to attract and maintain audience attention, build loyal communities, and thereby acquire celebrity capital. This labor involves producing content, engaging with followers, and managing their online presence authentically. For example, Blair Fowler’s gradual growth on YouTube, marked by slow but steady subscriber increases, exemplifies how sustained effort fosters perceived authenticity and celebrity capital. Fowler’s hands-on approach—handling scripting, filming, editing, and audience engagement—reflects the demanding nature of attention labor. Similarly, Michelle Phan’s early viral success on YouTube combined with emotional investment in her community highlights the blend of technical and relational work inherent in attention labor. Unlike traditional fame, attention labor focuses on becoming attention-worthy and monetizable within niche communities, even for micro- or nano-influencers. This practice contributes to community-oriented synergistic effects by fostering authentic, engaged audiences.

**Platform Agnosticism**  
Platform agnosticism involves translating an influencer’s unique perspective and content across multiple social media platforms. Influencers who tether their identity to a single platform risk short-lived careers; instead, they must adapt and repurpose content fluidly as platforms evolve. Michelle Phan’s pioneering approach—focusing on strong, relatable beauty content rather than any single platform—illustrates this practice. Influencers maintain consistency in niche or style while embracing new platforms, ensuring their celebrity capital remains portable and resilient. This adaptability enhances content-oriented synergistic effects by centering content quality over platform specificity.

**Advertising Practitioners as Talent Scouts**  
Advertising professionals act as talent scouts by identifying influencers who have already self-celebrified through their own attention labor and platform agnosticism. Unlike traditional celebrities who await discovery, social media influencers “break themselves” by consistently producing content and engaging audiences across platforms. For instance, Phan’s partnership with Lancôme emerged only after she had independently built a substantial following. Thus, advertising practitioners seek influencers who have organically acquired celebrity capital, avoiding premature or artificial intervention that could undermine authenticity.

### Collaborative Practices in the Influencer Celebrification Process

Collaborative practices expand celebrity capital by deepening connections among influencers, their audiences, and advertising practitioners. Two key collaborative practices are audience portability and creative ideation. Here, advertising practitioners serve as creative concierges, facilitating brand partnerships and maximizing the value of influencers’ celebrity capital.

**Audience Portability**  
Audience portability refers to the ability of influencers to transfer their engaged followers across platforms (e.g., podcasts, television, social media) and brand partnerships (e.g., cobranded products). The strength of an influencer’s celebrity capital lies not merely in follower count but in the passion and willingness of their audience to follow them into new ventures. For example, Michelle Phan’s launch of Ipsy demonstrated audience portability as fans migrated with her, expanding her renown and commercial opportunities. This practice fosters community-oriented synergistic effects by broadening and deepening the influencer’s community across diverse media and commercial contexts.

**Creative Ideation**  
Creative ideation is the collaborative, reciprocal process of content development between influencers and their audiences. It privileges the influencer’s unique voice while actively incorporating audience feedback and ideas, challenging traditional top-down expertise in content creation. Phan notes the shift from editor-driven trends to community-influenced content, highlighting the democratization of creative authority. Kristen, chief strategy officer at Digital Brand Architects, emphasizes that influencers who neglect audience engagement in creative decisions risk losing relevance. Unlike traditional celebrities who create content in isolation, influencers co-create with fans and peers, enhancing shareability and appeal. This diffusion of creative control contributes to content-oriented synergistic effects by producing authentic, audience-driven content.

**Advertising Practitioners as Creative Concierges**  
In collaborative practices, advertising practitioners act as creative concierges, facilitating and expanding creative partnerships between influencers and brands. They help both parties envision broader possibilities for leveraging celebrity capital while respecting the influencer’s authentic voice. Yolanda, CEO of Style Coalition, highlights the importance of preserving influencer authenticity to avoid diluting their brand through overt commercialization. Practitioners balance facilitation with minimal production control, recognizing that influencers must maintain creative authority to sustain audience trust. As Lina from Vogue notes, advertisers must accept limited control over influencer content, embracing the inherent unpredictability of influencer strategy. Graham, a digital agent, explains that creative concierges guide influencers to explore authentic opportunities that align with their brand and audience, reinforcing the iterative cycle where celebrity capital begets further celebrity capital.

### Evaluative Practices in the Influencer Celebrification Process

Evaluative practices legitimize the acquisition of celebrity capital by assessing an influencer’s value and potential to deliver promotional impact. Two key evaluative practices are content traversal and community-centric KPIs. Advertising practitioners function as impact analysts, measuring influencer relevance and success.

**Community-Centric KPIs**  
Rather than focusing solely on follower counts, community-centric KPIs emphasize qualitative measures of audience commitment and engagement to validate celebrity capital. While big data and quantitative metrics dominate influencer evaluation, our data reveal that authentic community bonds—such as follower nicknames, shared memes, and rituals—are critical indicators of an influencer’s value. Brian from Procter & Gamble likens this to “earning the right to be invited to the party,” underscoring the importance of genuine community integration. These qualitative indicators serve as a litmus test for brands seeking meaningful access to influencer audiences, reinforcing community-oriented synergistic effects.

### Summary

This framework illustrates influencer celebrification as an iterative, synergistic process involving generative, collaborative, and evaluative practices. Influencers acquire celebrity capital through dedicated attention labor and platform agnosticism, expand it via audience portability and creative ideation, and legitimize it through community-centric KPIs and content traversal. Advertising practitioners play crucial roles as talent scouts, creative concierges, and impact analysts, facilitating but not controlling the process to preserve influencer authenticity. The interplay between influencer content, audience engagement, and platform dynamics differentiates influencer fame from traditional celebrity endorsements, emphasizing the fluid, community-driven nature of digital celebrity capital.

If somebody doesn’t have a strong following on their own, just by virtue of the fact that they are someone in their peer group that people really look to for information, then they’re really not of value to our advertisers. We certainly don’t want to do anything to build up their following if it’s just not warranted naturally.

### Generative Practices in Influencer Celebrification

Generative influencer celebrification practices allow influencers to acquire seemingly authentic celebrity capital, positioning them as viable brand partners. Advertising practitioners cannot bolster or break social media stars because such commercial interference would fundamentally undermine their realness. An influencer’s celebrity capital is most valuable without direct corporate intervention.

### Collaborative Practices in the Influencer Celebrification Process

The influencer celebrification process continues through collaborative practices that expand the acquisition of celebrity capital. Two key collaborative practices are audience portability and creative ideation. Practitioners act as creative concierges, facilitating brand partnerships and commodifying influencers’ celebrity capital across platforms.

#### Audience Portability

Influencers, like traditional celebrities, gain fame through fan attention. Without fans and followers, influencers would not exist. Audience portability refers to the ability to transport audiences across platforms (e.g., podcasts, television, social media) and unique brand partnerships (e.g., cobranded product lines). The relationship between influencer and audience drives this portability.

Fans are willing to follow their favorite influencers into new ventures, contributing to celebrity capital acquisition. Jacob (CEO, United Talent Agency) notes that effective influencers create consistently engaging content that keeps audiences returning and enables influence beyond online spaces. The value of an influencer lies in the commitment and passion of their audience, not just follower count. For example, Michelle Phan’s launch of Ipsy demonstrated audience portability as fans migrated with her, expanding her renown and commercial opportunities. Audience portability broadens and deepens the influencer’s community, contributing to community-oriented synergistic effects within influencer celebrification.

#### Creative Ideation

Creative ideation is a collaborative, reciprocal content development process between influencers and their audiences. It privileges the influencer’s unique voice while actively incorporating audience feedback, challenging traditional top-down expertise in content creation. Phan explains that the community now holds significant influence over trends, replacing editor-driven models.

Authority and expertise remain important in commodifying celebrity capital, but influencer culture questions the sole value of experts. Influencers solicit ideas and feedback from their audiences, sharing creative responsibilities. Kristen (chief strategy officer, Digital Brand Architects) emphasizes that influencers who neglect audience engagement risk losing relevance. Unlike traditional celebrities who create content in isolation, influencers co-create with fans and peers, enhancing shareability and appeal. This diffusion of creative control contributes to content-oriented synergistic effects within influencer celebrification.

#### Advertising Practitioners as Creative Concierges

In collaborative practices, advertising practitioners act as creative concierges, facilitating and expanding partnerships between influencers and brands. They encourage both parties to envision broader possibilities for leveraging celebrity capital while respecting influencer authenticity.

Yolanda (CEO, Style Coalition) highlights the importance of preserving influencer authenticity to avoid diluting their brand through overt commercialization. Practitioners balance facilitation with minimal production control, recognizing that influencers must maintain creative authority to sustain audience trust. Lina (senior marketing manager, Vogue) notes that advertisers must accept limited control over influencer content, embracing the inherent unpredictability of influencer strategy. Patrick (director of corporate communications, Procter & Gamble) explains that unlike traditional celebrity endorsements, influencer strategy involves relinquishing control over content transfer.

Graham (digital agent, United Talent Agency) describes the creative concierge role as helping influencers explore authentic opportunities aligned with their brand and audience, reinforcing the iterative cycle where celebrity capital begets further celebrity capital. Advertising practitioners capitalize on influencer audiences and scale creative ideas to develop campaigns and transport audiences, reinforcing influencer celebrification.

### Evaluative Practices in the Influencer Celebrification Process

Evaluative practices legitimize the acquisition of celebrity capital by assessing influencer value and promotional impact. Two key evaluative practices are community-centric KPIs and content traversal. Advertising practitioners function as impact analysts, measuring influencer relevance and success.

#### Community-Centric KPIs

Celebrity capital is legitimized not by follower count but by demonstrating quality and commitment to followers. Community-centric KPIs involve qualitative assessments of audience commitment, such as follower nicknames, shared memes, and rituals, which validate celebrity capital beyond quantitative metrics.

Thomas (chief revenue officer, LASIA) acknowledges the dominance of big data but emphasizes that influencer celebrification cannot be captured by numbers alone. Brian (associate director of corporate communications, Procter & Gamble) describes community-centric KPIs as a litmus test for influencers to legitimize their celebrity capital and for brands to gain meaningful access to influencer audiences. This practice contributes to community-oriented synergistic effects within influencer celebrification.

#### Content Traversal

Content traversal tracks the movement of influencer content across and between platforms, reflecting the spread and stickiness of content beyond the influencer’s original community. Erik (manager of digital analytics, Burson-Marstellar) explains that monitoring how content travels and how audiences respond forms a feedback loop that informs targeting and positioning strategies.

Content traversal is foundational to influencer celebrification, as audiences disseminate content across social media, legitimizing celebrity capital. Landon (director of analytics products, Burson Cohn & Wolfe) describes this as a “perpetual survey” that instantaneously gauges audience reaction. Mark (executive vice president, Brandwatch) notes that content traversal must be evaluated frequently to keep pace with rapid content movement. Betsy (executive director of creative services, Vogue) highlights that content is often shared multiple times across platforms within 24 hours.

Understanding content traversal allows brands to identify influencers with widespread celebrity capital capable of reaching broad, cross-platform audiences. This reciprocal dynamic between branded and influencer content amplifies celebrity capital, creating more opportunities for brand partnerships and economic value. Content traversal contributes to content-oriented synergistic effects within influencer celebrification.

#### Advertising Practitioners as Impact Analysts

Advertising practitioners assess the value of celebrity capital and determine how much an influencer needs to maintain success. Ben (Synthesio) stresses the importance of moving beyond surface metrics like likes and views to deeply engage with online communities and evaluate brand integration within those communities.

Traditional social media metrics focus on individual platforms and tactics, but community-driven KPIs better capture the effectiveness of influencer advertising. Cherie (director of strategic planning, Burson Cohn & Wolfe) explains that customized measurement practices tailored to client goals provide more accurate assessments of return on investment, moving beyond dollar values to qualitative outcomes.

Clients must adapt evaluation models to the unique nature of influencer advertising rather than relying solely on traditional media metrics. This approach reinforces the legitimacy and monetization potential of celebrity capital within influencer celebrification.

### Summary

This restructured content clarifies the iterative process of influencer celebrification through generative, collaborative, and evaluative practices, emphasizing the distinct roles of advertising practitioners and the synergistic interplay between influencers, audiences, and platforms. It preserves all key concepts and practitioner insights while enhancing flow and focus on how celebrity capital is acquired, expanded, and legitimized in the digital advertising ecosystem.

### Community-Centric Practices and Celebrity Capital Acquisition

Influencers acquire celebrity capital by proving the closeness and uniqueness of their communities, which legitimizes their status. Influencers often point to their communities as evidence of celebrity, with community members acting as ad hoc influencers within these networks. Unlike traditional celebrities legitimized by achievements in substantive domains (e.g., sports, television), influencers operate within the attention economy. Community-centric KPIs represent evaluative practices that validate celebrity capital and its potential for monetization. Judah (head of marketing, Judgex) emphasizes that measuring “engagement” alone is insufficient; understanding who participates in online engagement is crucial. Thus, community-centric KPIs foster community-oriented synergistic effects within influencer celebrification, with audience commitment directly appealing to brands.

### Content Traversal: Tracking Cross-Platform Movement

Social media content now traverses multiple platforms, with influencer content frequently reposted across TikTok, Twitter, Instagram Reels, and others. Content traversal—tracking this movement—is an emergent evaluative practice critical to influencer advertising. Erik (manager of digital analytics, Burson-Marsteller) explains:

> “We watch to see where that message goes—how it travels through media. We understand what the potential impact is based on the audiences that pick it up. We watch to see how the audience responds. We figure out how to target, then we watch the response. At the end, we look and we see, ‘Okay, who did we miss?’ This feeds back to the beginning and helps us figure out: How do we position this? Who do we talk to? It is this whole wonderful cycle.”

Tracking content movement is foundational to influencer celebrification, as audiences disseminate content, legitimizing celebrity capital. Landon (director of analytics products, Burson Cohn & Wolfe) describes this as a “perpetual survey” that instantaneously gauges audience reaction. Mark (executive vice president, Brandwatch) notes content traversal requires near real-time evaluation due to rapid content movement, while Betsy (executive director of creative services, Vogue) highlights that content is often shared multiple times across platforms within 24 hours.

Understanding how branded and influencer content move across platform geographies and digital borders amplifies celebrity capital. Brand partnerships with influencers boost both parties’ celebrity capital, creating a reciprocal dynamic that increases monetizable opportunities. Content traversal thus contributes to content-oriented synergistic effects within influencer celebrification, distinguishing influencer fame from traditional celebrity endorsements. Tracking conversations and consumer engagement with content offers a holistic view of influencer celebrification.

### Advertising Practitioners as Impact Analysts

Advertising practitioners play a critical role in evaluating the value of celebrity capital and determining the influencer’s needs for sustained success. Ben (Synthesio) stresses moving beyond surface metrics like likes and views to deeply engage with online communities and assess brand integration within those communities:

> “There’s always a point where someone in that management ladder stops and says, ‘Well so what? Why are we here? What does it all mean? Great, we have 100,000 likes now and viral videos with millions of views, but has it really helped?’”

Traditional social media metrics focus on individual platforms and tactics, but community-driven KPIs better capture the effectiveness of influencer advertising. Cherie (director of strategic planning, Burson Cohn & Wolfe) explains that customized measurement practices tailored to client goals provide more accurate assessments of return on investment, moving beyond dollar values to qualitative outcomes:

> “With every client at the beginning, we would say ‘Okay, this is the investment that we have. Let’s look at these measurable outcomes we are trying to achieve as they relate to the influencers themselves.’ . . . That is not a very accurate way of assessing what the return actually was and, again, that used to be associated with a dollar value, but now it can be much more qualitative.”

Clients must adapt evaluation models to the unique nature of influencer advertising rather than relying solely on traditional media metrics. This approach reinforces the legitimacy and monetization potential of celebrity capital within influencer celebrification.

### Discussion: Distinctiveness of Influencer Celebrification

Traditional celebrity capital is built through accumulated media visibility in substantive domains largely independent of audience interaction. In contrast, influencers synergistically accrue celebrity capital through both content and community engagement. Our study highlights key distinctions in the celebrification process for influencers relative to traditional celebrities. Influencers’ celebrity capital is built through direct interaction with their audience and responsiveness to their requests. The active creation of conversations within an influencer’s community and the resulting cross-platform content spread foster additional layers of celebrity capital. Advertising practitioners amplify these processes through commercial associations, further growing influencers’ celebrity capital.

### Theoretical Implications

Extending prior work on celebrity capital and influencer advertising, this study articulates influencer celebrification as a process within an interconnected social media advertising ecosystem. It identifies six emergent practices grouped into three categories:

- **Generative practices:** attention labor and platform agnosticism  
- **Collaborative practices:** audience portability and creative ideation  
- **Evaluative practices:** community-centric KPIs and content traversal  

These practices produce community-oriented synergistic effects (attention labor, audience portability, community-centric KPIs) and content-oriented synergistic effects (platform agnosticism, creative ideation, content traversal).

Our findings challenge the reliance on traditional celebrity endorsement frameworks, emphasizing the need for theoretical models grounded in influencer-specific functions, experiences, and culture. Conceptualizing influencers merely as microcelebrities or subsets of celebrities risks minimizing their unique power and value in modern promotional culture. Influencer celebrification is a dynamic, process-oriented phenomenon shaped by the influencer’s community, which actively dictates content preferences and dissemination.

This study shifts the theoretical focus from the “being” and “doing” of influencer advertising to the “becoming” aspect, underscoring the iterative nature of influencer celebrification rather than viewing social media influencers as static statuses. Future research should explore how influencers maintain or lose celebrity capital, potentially differing from traditional celebrity decelebrification.  
The concept of influencer celebrification recognizes the distinct process of attaining celebrity capital, thus answering the call for theorization within the celebrity life cycle (Carrillat and Ilicic 2019). Future research might explore the varied types of celebrity capital influencers gain through the process of influencer celebrification and boundary conditions within which influencer celebrification unfolds. Attention, authenticity, and engagement are central to the appeal of influencers (Hearn and Schoenhoff 2016). But these concepts often go unquestioned as “good” practices of influencer advertising. The emergent theoretical concept of influencer celebrification calls into question terms like authenticity. For instance, influencers might hack influencer celebrification to gain celebrity capital in seemingly authentic but immoral or deviant ways (e.g., spreading health misinformation). More research is needed in this vein. Scholarship is also needed to explore influencer celebrification across a diverse set of influencers. For example, biases may exist in attention labor, for example, as influencer content is a function of “popularity” within a potentially oppressive social media landscape. One would like to believe this is an equal opportunity process, but previous research demonstrates algorithmic biases (Bishop 2021; Noble 2018). Are there algorithmic forces that oppress or democratize influencer celebrification for historically excluded populations, for example?  
Our research acknowledges theoretical slippages between the categories of celebrity and influencer in prior literature. And indeed, the current research raises the question: Can influencer celebrification be applied to celebrities as a theoretical frame? SMIs can become more traditional celebrities (e.g., comedian Liza Koshy was an online influencer turned celebrity television host) and traditional celebrities can become primarily SMIs (e.g., retired American gymnast Shawn Johnson primarily uses Instagram for promotional influencer content). Theoretical framing must acknowledge and explore movement between categories of celebrity and influencer, along with unique liabilities for engaging in influencer celebrification. Recognizing such oscillations will advance theoretical insights for both influencer advertising and celebrity endorsement.  

### Practical Implications  
Understanding the roles of advertising practitioners (e.g., talent scouts, creative concierges, impact analysts) in the influencer celebrification process carries practical implications for the rapidly professionalizing influencer industry (Freberg et al. 2011). Some of the first influencer campaigns launched in the mid-2000s, when YouTube and Facebook were novel media outlets. Nearly two decades later—with the emergence of interconnected and interactive platforms (e.g., TikTok, Twitch)—influencers themselves have become entrepreneurs, launching their own product lines and hiring agents to negotiate their contracts. Likewise, the influencer advertising industry has adapted quickly, with new in-house influencer marketing teams, advertising agencies dedicated to influencer campaigns, and sophisticated analytics to track influencer success. The days of influencer advertising being a niche do-it-yourself domain have passed. Our research shows there is value in investing in influencer advertising in and of itself independent from the behemoth category of social media advertising and with a distinct approach relative to traditional celebrity endorsements. Social media advertising as a field of expertise is not synonymous with influencer advertising; it requires a unique skill set. Influencer advertising practitioners must toe a careful line: contributing to the influencer celebrification process in ways that preserve influencer authenticity while also leveraging influencers’ accrued capital for commercial means.  

In traditional celebrity endorsement, clearly defined boundaries exist between celebrities as the “hired” face of a campaign relative to advertising experts and practitioners. In contrast, our research shows slippages between how a “practitioner” or expert is defined. Influencers are hired by companies and advertising agencies, but they are also advertising experts themselves, with well-developed experience in promoting their own personal brands—themselves. Influencers are an important resource for developing creative strategies beyond being merely hired for “sponcon” (sponsored content). Influencers differ from traditional celebrities in that they are experts in the medium upon which their celebrity capital is typically leveraged: social media. When we consider how expertise is culled in the influencer advertising domain, influencers themselves should be looked to for their unique expertise. A key to leveraging influencer celebrification is to shift how advertising practitioners view the role of influencers; that is, influencers do not work for a brand; influencers work with a brand. The relationship between influencers, practitioners, and, importantly, online communities should be conceived of as symbiotic rather than hierarchical. As such, all perspectives should be equally weighted.

While much of the power has shifted to the hands of influencers and their followers, our study suggests advertising practitioners play a key role in contributing to influencer celebrification. This reveals new opportunities for advertising practitioners to leverage their own power in the process. For instance, advertising practitioners can turn inward to brand employees to identify potential brand influencers. Platforms such as TikTok increasingly provide a behind the scenes look at business operations from the view of factory and frontline workers. With careful curation and creative idea generation, such content has the potential to positively impact the brand reputation. This is even more critical when we consider how content moves across and between media borders, often catapulted by the community rather than the brand or influencer. This points to a need for more expansive measurement of influencer advertising, beyond single platform metrics.

Instagram’s celebrity status verification process offers a practical example of how platforms recognize and authenticate celebrity capital. The platform uses a blue checkmark badge to confirm the authenticity of public figures, celebrities, and brands, aiming to prevent impersonation and help users find genuine accounts. Verification criteria include authenticity, uniqueness, completeness of profile, and notability, often demonstrated by media presence and public interest. Users can request verification through the Instagram app by submitting identification documents, though approval is not guaranteed and is reviewed based on these criteria. Verified accounts benefit from increased credibility, higher search ranking, and protection against impersonation. While this verification process is distinct from influencer celebrification, it relates closely to the recognition and legitimization of celebrity capital on social media platforms, complementing the theoretical framework by illustrating institutional acknowledgment of influencer status.

To effectively track and evaluate influencer celebrification, advertising practitioners increasingly rely on specialized social media monitoring and analytics tools. These platforms enable real-time tracking of influencer activity, audience engagement, and content traversal across multiple social media channels, providing comprehensive insights into the acquisition and leverage of celebrity capital. Leading tools such as Meltwater, Sprout Social, Hootsuite, and Agorapulse offer functionalities including sentiment analysis, influencer identification, campaign performance tracking, and cross-platform content monitoring. For example, Meltwater’s media intelligence platform allows practitioners to monitor influencer mentions and brand integration across social networks, featuring customizable dashboards and AI-powered insights. Sprout Social integrates social media management with monitoring and advanced analytics, providing detailed audience engagement metrics and content scheduling capabilities. Hootsuite and Agorapulse facilitate community management and track content dissemination patterns, essential for understanding content traversal and audience portability. Additionally, platforms like Synthesio and Brandwatch specialize in advanced analytics and ROI tracking, while Talkwalker excels in real-time audience insights and sentiment analysis across multiple channels. Mention and BuzzSumo focus on brand mentions and content performance, and YouScan adds visual content recognition to the evaluative toolkit. Integrating these tools into influencer marketing strategies supports the evaluative practices central to influencer celebrification, enabling practitioners to move beyond surface-level metrics and capture nuanced community-centric KPIs. This technological infrastructure is vital for sustaining the iterative, synergistic process of influencer celebrification in a dynamic digital ecosystem.

Complementing these analytics tools, influencer and celebrity databases have become indispensable resources for brands and advertising practitioners seeking to identify, evaluate, and engage influencers with established or emerging celebrity capital. These databases aggregate influencer profiles, contact information, audience demographics, engagement metrics, and historical campaign data, streamlining the talent scouting and partnership process. There are two primary types of influencer databases: opt-in platforms where influencers voluntarily register and provide verified data, and scraped databases that compile publicly available information from social media profiles. Pricing models vary, often based on subscription tiers, pay-per-use, or enterprise licensing, reflecting the depth and exclusivity of data access. Leading platforms such as AspireIQ, Upfluence, CreatorIQ, and Traackr offer comprehensive influencer marketing suites that integrate database access with campaign management and analytics, facilitating seamless collaboration between influencers and brands. Agencies specializing in influencer marketing also maintain proprietary databases, providing curated access to celebrity-status influencers and tailored matchmaking services. The strategic use of these databases enhances the collaborative and evaluative practices within influencer celebrification by enabling precise identification of influencers whose celebrity capital aligns with brand objectives, optimizing creative ideation and community-centric KPIs. Thus, influencer databases serve as critical infrastructure bridging theoretical insights with practical execution in the digital advertising ecosystem.

In addition to these established platforms, several top influencer marketing platforms have emerged as strategic tools for efficiently finding and managing influencers with celebrity status. These platforms combine AI-powered influencer discovery, audience insights, campaign management, fraud detection, and relationship management to streamline the influencer celebrification process for brands and agencies. Examples include:

- **Afluencer:** Focuses on influencer discovery and campaign management with an emphasis on authentic collaborations and community engagement.  
- **HYPR:** Offers a vast influencer database with detailed audience demographics and real-time analytics, supporting precise targeting and ROI measurement.  
- **Upfluence:** Provides AI-driven influencer search, campaign workflow automation, and performance tracking, enabling brands to identify influencers with strong celebrity capital and manage partnerships effectively.  
- **AspireIQ:** Combines influencer discovery with content creation tools and relationship management, facilitating collaborative creative ideation and sustained community engagement.  
- **CreatorIQ:** Integrates influencer identification, fraud detection, and cross-platform monitoring, ensuring brand safety and maximizing the value of celebrity capital.  
- **GRIN:** Focuses on end-to-end influencer marketing operations, including recruitment, content approval, and payment processing, supporting seamless collaboration and evaluative practices.  
- **Sprout Social:** While primarily a social media management tool, it also offers influencer identification and engagement features, complementing campaign analytics and community-centric KPIs.

Pricing models for these platforms typically involve subscription tiers based on the number of users, campaign volume, or access to premium features such as advanced analytics and AI capabilities. By leveraging these platforms, brands and agencies can efficiently identify influencers with established or emerging celebrity capital, vet their authenticity and audience quality, and manage collaborations that align with strategic marketing goals. These tools enhance the iterative and synergistic nature of influencer celebrification by supporting generative, collaborative, and evaluative practices within a unified technological framework.

For individuals aspiring to become digital influencers and engage in the process of influencer celebrification, several practical steps align closely with the theoretical concepts outlined above. First, identifying a clear niche or area of authentic interest is essential to build a distinct personal brand that resonates with a specific community. Authenticity and a unique voice are critical, as they foster trust and engagement, which are foundational to acquiring celebrity capital. Consistently creating high-quality, relevant content tailored to the chosen niche helps maintain audience interest and supports platform agnosticism by enabling content traversal across multiple social media channels. Engaging actively with the audience—responding to comments, participating in conversations, and fostering community—leverages attention labor and enhances audience portability, further legitimizing celebrity capital. Selecting appropriate social media platforms based on where the target community is most active ensures efficient use of resources and maximizes reach. Collaborating with brands and other influencers strategically can amplify creative ideation and expand community-centric KPIs, reinforcing the influencer’s celebrification process. Utilizing relevant hashtags and staying attuned to trending topics can increase content visibility and foster organic growth. Employing social media management tools such as Hootsuite or Sprout Social can aid in scheduling content, monitoring engagement, and analyzing performance, thereby supporting sustained attention labor and community engagement. Patience is vital, as building celebrity capital is iterative and requires sustained effort over time. By following these steps, aspiring influencers can effectively navigate the complex ecosystem of influencer celebrification, balancing authenticity with commercial opportunities while fostering a symbiotic relationship with their communities and advertising practitioners.

A notable but controversial tactic related to influencer celebrification is the practice of buying Instagram followers. Some influencers or brands may resort to purchasing followers to artificially inflate their audience size, aiming to appear more popular and thereby attract brand partnerships or increase perceived celebrity capital. However, this practice carries significant risks. Purchased followers are often fake or inactive accounts, which do not engage authentically with content, undermining community-centric KPIs and the genuine attention labor foundational to influencer celebrification. Moreover, platforms like Instagram actively penalize accounts that engage in such practices, potentially reducing reach or suspending accounts. This contrasts sharply with the organic follower growth emphasized in influencer celebrification theory, which values authentic community engagement and audience portability. While buying followers might offer short-term visibility, it jeopardizes long-term legitimacy and monetization potential by eroding trust with both audiences and advertising practitioners. Thus, the practice of buying followers highlights tensions within influencer celebrification between authenticity and commercial pressures, underscoring the importance of genuine community-building in acquiring sustainable celebrity capital.

### Instagram Influencer Marketing Case Studies

To bridge the theoretical framework of influencer celebrification with real-world marketing practice, examining notable Instagram influencer marketing case studies provides concrete insights into how celebrity capital is acquired and leveraged effectively.

**1. Daniel Wellington’s Influencer Strategy**  
Daniel Wellington, a watch brand, famously built its global presence through collaborations with micro- and macro-influencers on Instagram. The campaign’s objective was to increase brand awareness and drive sales by leveraging authentic influencer content. Influencers were encouraged to create personalized posts featuring the watches, often accompanied by unique discount codes. This strategy capitalized on audience portability and creative ideation, as influencers tailored content to their communities. The campaign resulted in exponential growth in followers and sales, demonstrating the power of community-centric KPIs and content traversal as influencer posts were widely shared across platforms. The brand’s success exemplifies generative practices (attention labor), collaborative practices (creative ideation), and evaluative practices (community-centric KPIs and content traversal) working synergistically within influencer celebrification.

**2. Glossier’s Community-Driven Approach**  
Glossier, a beauty brand, emphasizes community engagement by partnering with influencers who are also customers and brand advocates. Their strategy focuses on authentic storytelling and user-generated content, fostering attention labor and platform agnosticism. Influencers create content that resonates deeply with their followers, encouraging organic sharing and content traversal. This approach has cultivated strong celebrity capital for both the brand and its influencers, with measurable increases in engagement rates and brand loyalty. Glossier’s model highlights the importance of collaborative and evaluative practices, where influencer content and audience participation co-create value, reinforcing the iterative nature of influencer celebrification.

### Practical Guide: How Brands Can Effectively Use Social Media Influencers for Brand Promotion

To maximize the benefits of influencer celebrification, brands should adopt a strategic, multi-step approach to influencer marketing that aligns with the core concepts of celebrity capital acquisition and legitimacy.

1. **Identify Suitable Influencers:**  
   Brands must select influencers whose personal brand, values, and audience demographics align closely with the brand’s identity and target market. This ensures authenticity and relevance, fostering stronger community-centric KPIs. Utilizing influencer marketing platforms and databases (e.g., AspireIQ, Upfluence, CreatorIQ) can streamline this discovery process by providing detailed audience insights and engagement metrics.

2. **Define Clear Campaign Goals and KPIs:**  
   Establishing specific, measurable objectives—such as brand awareness, engagement rates, website traffic, or sales conversions—guides campaign design and evaluation. Community-centric KPIs should be prioritized over superficial metrics like follower counts to capture genuine audience interaction and attention labor.

3. **Collaborate on Authentic Content Creation:**  
   Co-creating content with influencers leverages their expertise in creative ideation and platform-specific storytelling. Authenticity is key; campaigns should empower influencers to produce content that resonates naturally with their communities, enhancing audience portability and content traversal.

4. **Leverage Multiple Social Media Platforms:**  
   Encouraging content dissemination across various platforms (Instagram, TikTok, YouTube, Twitter) maximizes reach and supports platform agnosticism. Tracking content traversal through analytics tools helps brands understand cross-platform impact and optimize future campaigns.

5. **Engage Influencer Communities:**  
   Brands should foster two-way communication by encouraging influencers to interact with their followers, respond to comments, and build trust. This deepens community engagement, reinforcing the influencer’s celebrity capital and the brand’s reputation.

6. **Measure and Analyze Campaign Performance:**  
   Employing advanced analytics and social media monitoring tools enables brands to assess campaign effectiveness in real time. Evaluative practices focusing on community-centric KPIs and content traversal provide nuanced insights beyond traditional metrics, informing iterative improvements.

7. **Address Challenges and Best Practices:**  
   Brands must be vigilant against influencer fraud, inauthentic engagement, and misalignment of values. Transparent communication, clear contracts, and ongoing relationship management help mitigate risks and maximize ROI.

By integrating these steps within the influencer celebrification framework, brands can harness the synergistic interplay of generative, collaborative, and evaluative practices to build sustainable celebrity capital, foster authentic community connections, and achieve impactful marketing outcomes.

### Recommended Cameras and Equipment for Influencer Photography

The quality and professionalism of content creation tools play a crucial role in influencer celebrification, as high-quality visuals contribute to audience engagement, creative ideation, and the accumulation of celebrity capital. Influencers often select cameras and equipment that balance technical capabilities with portability and ease of use to support consistent content production across platforms.

Key camera features important for influencer photography and videography include:

- **Video resolution:** 4K video capability is increasingly standard, enabling crisp, high-definition content suitable for platforms like YouTube, Instagram Reels, and TikTok.  
- **Autofocus:** Fast and reliable autofocus systems ensure sharp images and smooth video, especially for dynamic or self-shot content.  
- **Image stabilization:** In-body or lens-based stabilization reduces blur and shakiness, enhancing video quality without requiring extensive post-production.  
- **Portability:** Lightweight and compact designs facilitate on-the-go shooting and vlogging.  
- **Connectivity:** Built-in Wi-Fi or Bluetooth allows quick transfer of content to mobile devices for rapid editing and posting.

Popular camera models favored by influencers include:

- **Mirrorless cameras:** Sony A7 series (e.g., A7 III), Canon EOS R series, and Fujifilm X series offer excellent image quality, interchangeable lenses, and advanced video features.  
- **Compact vlogging cameras:** Sony ZV-1 and DJI Osmo Pocket are designed for ease of use, portability, and high-quality video, ideal for influencers who prioritize mobility.  
- **High-end smartphones:** Devices like the iPhone 14 Pro and Samsung Galaxy S23 Ultra feature advanced multi-lens camera systems with computational photography, making them versatile tools for influencer content creation.

Supporting equipment also enhances content quality and production value:

#### Ring Lights: Essential Lighting for Influencer Video Production

Among lighting options, ring lights have become a staple for influencer content creation, particularly for video production and beauty or lifestyle content. Ring lights provide even, soft illumination that reduces shadows and highlights facial features, enhancing the visual appeal of videos and photos. This lighting quality supports generative and collaborative practices in influencer celebrification by improving content quality, thereby increasing audience engagement and facilitating content traversal across platforms.

Key features of ring lights include:

- **Adjustable brightness:** Allows influencers to control light intensity to suit different environments and moods.  
- **Color temperature control:** Enables switching between warm, neutral, and cool light tones to match natural lighting or create desired effects.  
- **Size and portability:** Available in various diameters (typically 10 to 18 inches), with some models designed for easy transport and setup.  
- **Mounting options:** Many ring lights come with smartphone or camera mounts at the center, enabling hands-free shooting and optimal framing.  
- **Power sources:** Options include USB-powered models for portability and AC-powered units for more consistent output.

Popular ring light models favored by influencers include:

- **Neewer 18-inch Ring Light Kit:** Offers adjustable brightness and color temperature, with included tripod and phone holder, suitable for professional-quality content.  
- **Diva Ring Light Super Nova:** Known for high-quality light output and durability, popular among beauty influencers.  
- **Lume Cube Ring Light:** Compact and portable, ideal for on-the-go creators needing versatile lighting.  
- **Godox LR150:** Provides adjustable settings and excellent color rendering, favored for video production.

When purchasing a ring light, influencers should consider:

- The size appropriate for their shooting space and content style.  
- Compatibility with their camera or smartphone setup.  
- Portability needs if frequently shooting in different locations.  
- Budget, balancing quality and features.

Investing in a quality ring light enhances the influencer’s ability to produce visually appealing, professional content that resonates with audiences and supports the iterative, synergistic process of influencer celebrification.

### Recommended Cameras and Equipment for Influencer Photography

The quality and professionalism of content creation tools play a crucial role in influencer celebrification, as high-quality visuals contribute to audience engagement, creative ideation, and the accumulation of celebrity capital. Influencers often select cameras and equipment that balance technical capabilities with portability and ease of use to support consistent content production across platforms.

Key camera features important for influencer photography and videography include:

- **Video resolution:** 4K video capability is increasingly standard, enabling crisp, high-definition content suitable for platforms like YouTube, Instagram Reels, and TikTok.  
- **Autofocus:** Fast and reliable autofocus systems ensure sharp images and smooth video, especially for dynamic or self-shot content.  
- **Image stabilization:** In-body or lens-based stabilization reduces blur and shakiness, enhancing video quality without requiring extensive post-production.  
- **Portability:** Lightweight and compact designs facilitate on-the-go shooting and vlogging.  
- **Connectivity:** Built-in Wi-Fi or Bluetooth allows quick transfer of content to mobile devices for rapid editing and posting.

Popular camera models favored by influencers include:

- **Mirrorless cameras:** Sony A7 series (e.g., A7 III), Canon EOS R series, and Fujifilm X series offer excellent image quality, interchangeable lenses, and advanced video features.  
- **Compact vlogging cameras:** Sony ZV-1 and DJI Osmo Pocket are designed for ease of use, portability, and high-quality video, ideal for influencers who prioritize mobility.  
- **High-end smartphones:** Devices like the iPhone 14 Pro and Samsung Galaxy S23 Ultra feature advanced multi-lens camera systems with computational photography, making them versatile tools for influencer content creation.

Future research and practitioner efforts might explore how formal education and training influence the trajectory of influencer celebrification, potentially enhancing the legitimacy and sustainability of celebrity capital acquisition in the evolving digital advertising landscape.

Future research should seek to uncover how to quantitatively measure influencers’ celebrity capital, with a potential focus on developing a scale to capture this concept (see Gunter 2014). More in-depth longitudinal and ethnographic studies are also warranted, tracking the ebbs and flows of influencer celebrification as the structure of the influencer advertising industry evolves. Influencers, agents, and clients work across multinational contexts and must navigate cultural differences. Cross-cultural comparison in the acquisition of celebrity capital within the influencer industry could be a fruitful direction for future inquiry. To date, much of the policy-oriented research in influencer advertising focuses on misinformation and disclosure practices (Ershov and Mitchell 2020). These domains should continue to be explored through the lens of influencer celebrification; however, more critical research is needed to explore how vulnerable consumers (e.g., children) are privy to and exploited by the influencer celebrification process in influencer advertising. Policy research should consider the online conversations occurring between influencers and their followers, particularly as narratives may be manufactured to acquire more celebrity capital (e.g., influencers using clickbait psychology terms like gaslighting and narcissism; Dodgson and Colombo 2021).  

Indeed, despite the proliferation of social media platforms, much of the research to date focuses on examining influencer advertising on a single platform (e.g., Instagram influencers, YouTube influencers). Social media platforms come and go, but to have a lasting effect in an advertising campaign, brands must understand how SMIs withstand platform changes and bring their followers along with them for the ride. More specifically, extant research has focused predominantly on the content that appears on specific social media platforms and minimized the role of the community in contributing to the celebrification of the influencer. In the previous era of social media advertising, content was king; today, content and community are king. The domain in which influencers acquire celebrity capital—the Internet—is largely the same domain where their commercial value lies. For advertising practitioners, this is a fundamental shift from harnessing the power of a traditional celebrity. Advertising practitioners must recognize the creative agency and communal power underlying an influencer’s celebrity capital. Moreover, as influencers work with advertisers, this produces even more celebrity capital; the process becomes a continual loop.  

### Related Cultural Context: Contemporary Analyses of Fame  
To provide additional cultural and theoretical context for understanding fame and celebrity culture, it is worth noting Justine Bateman’s widely recognized book, *Fame: The Hijacking of Reality* (2018).
